Note that the RMP*eSubmit program requires that the quantity of each substance be rounded to the nearest pound (1 lbs), and that the impact radius be reported to two significant digits in miles (0.01 mi).  

No offsite receptors would be impacted under either scenario.  When not being handled for shipment, all Level 2 and 3 aerosols are stored on pallets within a dedicated explosion-proof room constructed with blast walls.  A secondary aerosol room is occasionally used for picking of small amounts of product on open pallets.  This room is in compliance with local fire codes for the aerosols.  There have been no prior accidents at the facility associated with this process.

This process has been incorporated into the facility's emergency response plans and safety programs.  These are provided to San Bernardino County (LEPC) and submitted to the California Unified Program Agencies (CUPA) California Environmental Reporting System (CERS) in the Emergency Contact Plan which is reviewed and updated annually.  Geodis maintains a Facility Emergency Action Plan which is also reviewed annually.  It was last revised March 13, 2017.  Facility managers and supervisors are required to complete the training.  All employees are also provided emergency response and safety training at the time of hiring and renewed annually.  The most recent training was completed on November 12, 2016.

A Risk Management Plan has been implemented at the Fontana, California facility for the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous materials. The warehouse facility is operated by Geodis logistics, and located at 13277 San Bernardino Avenue, Fontana (San Bernardino County), California. The facility is a storage and distribution warehouse that houses consumer products packaged in aerosol cans for The Scotts Company, LLC, which is headquartered in Marysville, Ohio.  Based on the materials and the processes and results of the offsite consequence analysis discussed below, this plan meets the requirements of Program 1.

The aerosol cans are manufactured by Ortho®, and consist of consumer product insecticides.  Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) propellant used in the aerosol products contains several components that are classified as flammable materials under EPA's RMP regulations.  Specifically, the propellants consist of propane, butane and isobutane blends.  The maximum potential quantities of aerosol products containing these substances were conservatively based on the maximum projected inventory for the facility (163,424, 18-oz cans) plus a 20% safety factor.  The maximum potential product propellant weights were used to estimate the maximum potential inventories of RMP-regulated chemicals in the warehouse storage process.  Although the actual amounts in the warehouse at any given time should be much lower, the estimated maximum potential amount of each substance is: 

¿	Isobutane:	45,963 lbs
¿	Butane:	        27,578 lbs
¿	Propane: 	27,578 lbs

A worst case scenario was performed using the EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance and provided software (RMP*Comp) for a vessel with the greatest amount of propellant mixture.  The maximum quantity of each substance in a single vessel is: 0.28 lbs isobutane, 0.17 lbs of butane, and 0.17 lbs of propane.
